citation.article-title: Clostridium saccharogumia sp. nov. and Lactonifactor longoviformis gen. nov., sp. nov., two novel human faecal bacteria involved in the conversion of the dietary phytoestrogen secoisolariciresinol diglucoside.

p.s: Description of Clostridium saccharogumia sp. nov.
C. saccharogumia (sac.cha.ro gu’ mi.a. Gr. neut. n. saccharon sugar, L. fem. n. gumia eater, N.L. fem. n. saccharogumia sugar eater).
Cells are Gram-positive helically coiled rods (0.9 μm wide and 2.0–3.0 μm long).
They are strictly anaerobic, catalase and indole negative.
The species grows between 25 and 45 °C but not at pH values below 6.0 and above 9.0.
It utilises cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, lactose, mannose, sucrose and salicin as the sole carbon and energy source.
Spore formation and motility were not observed.
The major cellular fatty acids are 16:0 (20.2%) and 17:1 w5c ISO (18.2%).
Colonies on Columbia-agar are circular, entire, up to 3 mm in diameter, convex to umbonate, opaque, greyish white and non-hemolytic.
The type strain SDG-Mt85-3DbT (=DSM 17460T=CCUG 51486T) was isolated from faeces of a healthy human male adult.
Its G+C content of DNA ranged between 29.4 and 31.7 mol%.
The strain was tolerant to rifampicin and metronidazole at concentrations of up to 15 μg ml−1.
